content.webTitle: Line of Duty recap: series three finale – urgent exit required!

fields.headline: Line of Duty recap: series three finale – urgent exit required!
fields.bodyText: OK everyone, and breathe. This was a super-size series finale with all the best and worst elements of Line of Duty on show. Among the best: the two incredibly tense and brilliantly scripted interrogation scenes. As for the worst: the final 15 minutes, which took a lurch into melodrama that only just paid off. One of the most interesting things about this show is the way it strives so hard to create an air of realism – the interrogations, the jargon, the integration of real-life events – only to undercut it all in the name of drama. The final minutes, featuring gunshots in HQ and an amusingly out-of-puff Kate chasing Dot all over an industrial wasteland, were ludicrously over-the-top (although admittedly we wouldn’t blink twice if this were the conclusion to an American cop show). Yet I can’t deny I thoroughly enjoyed the adrenaline shot they provided – and therein lies the Line of Duty conundrum. It’s clever and tightly plotted, but it’s also addicted to twists and has a tendency to go overboard at the last. That said, I did like the fact that Danny Waldron turned out to be a red herring. Yes, his death sparked the whole investigation and brought Dot down but the story ultimately told was very different from the one suggested at the start. I’m also interested to see where they go from here. One of the best things about this season has been the way it slowly revealed that everything tied together, that there was a wider conspiracy at play. A standalone fourth season would feel slightly out of place given those circumstances. I still have faith in Jed Mercurio, though: after all, he has kept me on the edge of my seat for the past six weeks. The bad guys Farewell to DI Matthew “Dot” Cottan: the weasel’s weasel and a man who I always managed to feel slightly sorry for despite his villainy. He started out on top of his game, framing Steve for the murder of Lindsay Denton, slipping in endless snide taunts (“See, it’s what these coppers do when you’ve got them bang to rights”; “Steve Arnott, golf tee – I think Danny Waldron was trying to tell us something”) and even having the foresight to get the file he doctored from Steve’s ex-girlfriend Nicola Rogerson, thus further undermining young Arnott. He ended the episode a paranoid mess, haunted by Denton’s ghost, on the run and eventually sacrificing his life to save Kate. Urgent exit required indeed (whatever I might think about the series end, that text was pure genius). Was Dot’s act of sacrifice plausible given how self-serving he’s always appeared? On balance I’d say yes. There’s always been a sense that, like Denton, Dot is as much victim as villain, desperate to escape the world he’s been trapped in since he was a boy. It’s also true that he has made numerous attempts this series to reach out to Kate, as though he saw her as his last chance for an ordinary life. The small moment where she admitted she did want to sleep with him was fascinating, zeroing in as it did on Dot’s surprising air of vulnerability, as was her final speech to him, which suggested that she differentiated between Dot and the “monsters” he protected. Speaking of monsters, will we ever know who they really are? I kept expecting Dot’s getaway driver to be a big reveal, but in the end he was just another anonymous bad guy. Perhaps that’s Mercurio’s wider point: it’s easy to trap one bad apple, but bringing down the whole barrel is a different, far more difficult game. The good guys Still, if anyone can do it it’s AC-12. With an increasingly distraught Steve under arrest for much of the episode the night belonged to Fleming and Hastings. Kate finally showed her undercover skills, successfully trailing Dot (well done to all the commenters who said she’d save the day) and collecting evidence against him. In truth, it was pretty obvious from early on that she was on Dot’s case – all that note taking during the first interview, plus the fact that Hastings ordered the trail on Arnott – but that didn’t make the subsequent night of chasing the paper trail any less enjoyable (then again, I am a sucker for stories where people sift through evidence to catch their man). It was especially great to see the excellent Vicky McClure given more to do – I loved it when she turned down Dot’s advice to get away with the pragmatic response: “I’m too knackered to run” – and by the end I felt quite warmly towards DC now DS Fleming, dubious undercover skills and all. Not as warmly as I felt towards superintendent Ted Hastings. From his weary despair over Steve’s arrest – “God help me if I ever get a good night’s sleep again” – to his increasing irritation with the slippery Gill (“Even after the time we’ve spent together, you really don’t know me at all”) Hastings dominated much of the first hour. In a show like this, it’s always useful to have one character that you entirely believe will do the right thing no matter the circumstances. Hastings is that man. Notes and observations Maneet remains the most awesome person on the show, possessing not only backbone and good policing skills but also demonstrating the ability to multi-task late at night with a small baby. Promote her to AC-12 ASAP please. The reveal that Steve had canoodled with Lindsay was one of the few things that bothered me – would Hastings really allow Steve back to AC-12 when he knows he behaved improperly? I know he has a soft spot for him, but wouldn’t that mean he’d buried evidence? I can’t see Hastings doing that at all. I did, however, feel sorry for Lindsay, her posthumous validation and her bleak funeral no one attended. I even managed to feel sympathy for Steve and his eyebrows thanks to Martin Compston’s emotional turn when Sam dumped him. Did we already know Hari had a gambling problem? I wasn’t sure if Dot just suggested that because it’s his own history or if he appropriated Hari’s story when talking to Kate about his dodgy past. Ted Hastings said “Mother of God” twice this week, so I’m calling it: he’s definitely Catholic. No, I have no idea why he joined the freemasons … perhaps he didn’t, but just refuses to answer any questions about his personal life. I enjoy imagining how many times a day Hastings has to say “like the battle”. There was something splendid about the fact that Nige survived to draw his pension. His survival skills are cockroach-levels of good. Weasel of the week I’m giving it to the fantastically patronising Gill Bigelow, a woman who managed to make the phrase “of course you care” sound like it was coated in poison. Quote of the week “There’s a line. It’s called right and wrong and I know which side my duty lies, so why don’t you write a nice letter of resignation to the PCC or I swear to god I will drag you down with the rest of them.” Superintendent Ted Hastings lays claim to the last part of my heart. What did you think? Was it a satisfying conclusion or did Mercurio drop the ball? Did Dot’s ending satisfy you or are you picking at loose ends. Finally, thank you to everyone who posted theories, crazy or otherwise, week after week. You’ve made this a joy to write and hopefully see you all back here next time …
